awd_titl_txt: Professional Identity Development in Civil Engineering Students with Disabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
Currently available statistics suggest that between 11 and 15% of U.S. college students identify as individuals with disabilities, yet little work addresses identity development within this population broadly, and even less explores their experiences within engineering. Calls from both disabilities studies and national organizations such as the American Institute for Research consistently ask educators to broaden participation in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math fields to include individuals with disabilities. Therefore, this work targets an urgent need in engineering education research. The study lays a foundation for broadening participation in engineering by enabling us to better understand the supports and barriers students with disabilities experience. Educators will be able to use the findings to develop inclusive educational experiences that promote identity formation, diversity, and universal design. At the same time, because the students will are followed into the workplace, the findings can benefit engineering employers as they hire engineers with disabilities, again focusing on systems and structures that support inclusion and accessibility. Moreover, the project will build bridges between the engineering education and disabilities studies community by establishing partnerships and bolstering ongoing conversations within engineering that help to move disability from the margins to the center.

The project addresses the call for studies on the "development of identity as an engineer and its intersection with other identities" by conducting a longitudinal study of students with disabilities in civil engineering. The project will use constructivist grounded theory to study two cohorts over three years. The first cohort follows 20 students from the fall of their first year through the spring of their junior year, with interviews twice a year (early fall and late spring). The second cohort, run concurrently, follows 20 students from spring of their junior year through their first year in the workplace, again with interviews twice a year. This approach spans the full undergraduate experience as well as the transition to work, and provides a rich data set from which to develop a theory of identity formation for this population. 

Consistent with grounded theory, the project does not impose an existing theory on the data; however, the understanding of identity broadly draws on social identity theory (SIT), which treats identities in terms of group membership developed through comparisons of values and behaviors members make with one another and with individuals belonging to other groups. This approach is consistent with existing studies of individuals with disabilities in college as well as with studies of professional identities, and allows the project team to situate the work within the broader landscape of identity research in engineering. The project addresses a significant gap in research on the professional formation of engineers by extending an emergent theoretical model of identity development in civil engineering to students with disabilities as they advance through their degree program and into the workforce. It provides significant contributions to research on identity development in engineering broadly, research on diversity and inclusion in engineering, and research on disability studies in higher education - issues that, to date, have seen little integration. The longitudinal approach advances our understanding of undergraduate development by capturing both how and why individuals with disabilities merge and negotiate personal and professional identities through these changes over time. The model developed in this study can then be used by researchers in other engineering fields and, potentially, beyond engineering to facilitate a more robust and nuanced understanding of how students with disabilities develop identities in college.

Overview: Disabled people continue to be significantly underrepresented in engineering. Current statistics suggest that approximately 26 percent of US adults have some form of disability. Yet only 6 percent of undergraduate students enrolled in engineering programs report as having a disability or identifying as disabled. This gap points to deeper issues of accessibility and inclusion within systems of higher education. To address these issues and enhance the recruitment and retention of students with disabilities, we conducted this study to gain a better understanding, meet the needs, and promote the success of this population in engineering programs.

The purpose of this study was to understand the ways students? experiences of their disabilities interacted with the process of becoming an engineer (or getting an engineering degree). To guide our work, we asked the following research questions: How do students with cognitive, developmental, or physical disabilities form identities as civil engineers (1)  during their undergraduate programs? and (2) during their first year at work? 

We addressed these questions by using a data-driven approach to examine how students experienced physical, cultural, and bureaucratic university structures as they navigated their undergraduate careers and entered into the workforce. This approach included interviewing study participants once per semester for up to three years. Over the course of the project, we conducted a total of 67 interviews with 30 participants who were identified as enrolled in, previously enrolled in, or recently graduated from a US civil engineering program. Participants identified as having a broad range of physical, cognitive, and developmental disabilities that included Postural Orthostatic Tachyardia Syndrome (POTS), Lyme Disease, Narcolepsy, Autism, Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD), and anxiety. To provide a meaningful point of comparison across institutions and a contexts for identifying and implementing research findings, we narrowed our study scope to civil engineering. Overall, our project had two overarching goals: (1) to expand the existing Advancing from Outsider to Insider (AOI) model of professional identity negotiation to include students with disabilities; and (2) to bring the voices and experiences of students with disabilities to the center of conversations as we build inclusive educational environments.

Intellectual Merit: The most significant outcome of this study expands the AOI Model of professional identity negotiation. While the AOI Model identifies various ways students negotiate their personal and professional identities as they become engineers, the process identified in this study provided deeper insights on the ways participants define themselves in relation to engineering and their disability in different contexts. That is, people?s disabilities become more or less relevant to them as they consider their experiences in terms of the accessibility of the physical environment, social norms, and the norms of civil engineering. Their assessment of the relevancy and impact of disability changes and evolves as students encounter physical, social, or institutional access barriers; manage accommodations requests and implementation; and navigate expectations of society and of the civil engineering discipline. Participants in our study continually revise their definitions of self and of the civil engineering profession ? including disability at varying degrees. If students with disabilities cannot reconcile their definitions of self and discipline, they lose their connection to their major (in this case, civil engineering) and often leave the field. A summary of the process of disability identity negotiation is summarized in Table 1 and illustrated in Figure 1. The model developed from this study can be used by researchers in and beyond engineering to help us better include and support students with disabilities as they enter college and move into the workforce.

Broader Impacts: Overall, this study contributes to larger efforts to move beyond mere tolerance and actively welcome a diverse range of students in engineering. By enabling us to better understand the supports and barriers students with disabilities experience, this study lays the foundation for broadening participation in engineering. Educators can draw from the participants? accounts that illustrate and explain the different aspects of the model to develop inclusive curricular and co-curricular structures that move beyond ?accommodation? to universal accessibility that makes engineering a field that welcomes everyone. We have already shared a number of strategies in journal articles, conference papers, and workshops for administrators, faculty, staff, and students both within and beyond engineering. Our findings also shed light on how students with disabilities experience career transitions as they move from school to work. University career centers and engineering employers can draw from students? experiences to create more inclusive and accessible hiring practices, such as helping students identify a position in engineering that aligns with their skills and provides opportunities for professional growth.
